title: Vasque Sunsetter NTX Review: The Ultimate Guide to Modern Heritage Hiking Boots
description: After spending six months testing the Vasque Sunsetter across various terrains from desert trails to mountain peaks, I've gathered comprehensive insights about this modern take on a hiking classic. Whether you're considering upgrading from sneakers or replacing worn-out boots, this detailed review covers everything you need to know about Vasque's sustainable approach to trail footwear. For more hiking gear recommendations, visit our homepage for expert outdoor equipment guides.

              "text": "The Vasque Sunsetter offers good value for hikers seeking a comfortable, waterproof boot with modern features. Best suited for day hikes and light backpacking rather than extreme conditions."
            }
          },
          {
            "@type": "Question",
            "name": "How does the Vasque Sunsetter compare to the original Sundowner?",
            "@id": "#faq2",
            "position": 2,
            "acceptedAnswer": {
              "@type": "Answer",
              "text": "The Sunsetter is lighter (997g vs 1200g+) and more comfortable than the original Sundowner, featuring modern cushioning and sustainable materials. However, it sacrifices some durability - the original Italian-made Sundowner was known for lasting decades, while the Sunsetter prioritizes comfort and lighter weight over extreme longevity."
            }
          },
          {
            "@type": "Question",
            "name": "What sizes and colors are available for the Vasque Sunsetter?",
            "@id": "#faq3",
            "position": 3,
            "acceptedAnswer": {
              "@type": "Answer",
              "text": "The Vasque Sunsetter is available in men's sizes 7-14 and women's sizes 6-12, both with half sizes. Color options include Lion (tan/brown), Ebony (dark brown/black), and Thyme (olive green). The boots tend to run slightly narrow, so wide-footed hikers may need to size up or consider alternative models."
            }
          },
          {
            "@type": "Question",
            "name": "Is the Nature-Tex waterproofing effective in wet conditions?",
            "@id": "#faq4",
            "position": 4,
            "acceptedAnswer": {
              "@type": "Answer",
              "text": "Yes, the Nature-Tex membrane provides reliable waterproofing for stream crossings, wet trails, and light snow. Made with 50% recycled materials, it offers breathability comparable to Gore-Tex. However, like all waterproof membranes, it requires proper DWR treatment maintenance on the outer leather to perform optimally."
            }
          },
          {
            "@type": "Question",
            "name": "How long is the break-in period for Vasque Sunsetter boots?",
            "@id": "#faq5",
            "position": 5,
            "acceptedAnswer": {
              "@type": "Answer",
              "text": "The Vasque Sunsetter has a relatively short break-in period of 2-3 short hikes or about 15-20 miles of walking. The soft suede upper and padded collar minimize hot spots. I recommend wearing them around town for a few days before your first serious hike to ensure proper fit and comfort."
            }
          }
        ]
      }
    }

body:
Vasque Sunsetter NTX Review: The Ultimate Guide to Modern Heritage Hiking Boots

After spending six months testing the Vasque Sunsetter across various terrains from desert trails to mountain peaks, I've gathered comprehensive insights about this modern take on a hiking classic. Whether you're considering upgrading from sneakers or replacing worn-out boots, this detailed review covers everything you need to know about Vasque's sustainable approach to trail footwear. For more hiking gear recommendations, visit our homepage for expert outdoor equipment guides.

Table of Contents

• Overview and First Impressions • Design and Construction Analysis • Trail Performance Testing • My Personal Experience • Comparison and Value Analysis • Frequently Asked Questions • Final Verdict and Recommendations

Overview and First Impressions

The Vasque Sunsetter represents a significant evolution from the legendary Sundowner, trading some traditional durability for modern comfort and sustainability. When I first unboxed these boots, the immediate impression was one of refined craftsmanship - the soft suede upper feels premium, and the iconic red laces immediately signal Vasque heritage.

Inspired by the 1984 Sundowner that built Vasque's reputation, the Sunsetter incorporates contemporary materials and construction techniques. The most notable upgrade is the Nature-Tex waterproof membrane, manufactured with 50% recycled content, replacing traditional Gore-Tex in Vasque's sustainability push. At 2 pounds 2 ounces for a men's size 9, these boots strike a balance between support and weight that's immediately noticeable on the trail.

Key Specifications at a Glance

Weight: 2 lbs 2 oz (997g)
Upper: 1.4-1.6mm suede leather
Waterproofing: Nature-Tex membrane
Midsole: Compression molded EVA
Outsole: Vasque Micro Plus
Colors: Lion, Ebony, Thyme

The build quality feels solid without being overly robust - this isn't a boot designed for extreme mountaineering or multi-week expeditions. Instead, Vasque has positioned the Sunsetter as an everyday adventure boot, suitable for day hikes, weekend backpacking trips, and urban exploration. The molded mesh collar provides ankle support while allowing natural movement, and the anatomical footbed suggests comfort was a primary design consideration.

Check Current Price on Amazon

What immediately sets the Sunsetter apart from budget hiking boots is the attention to sustainable materials. The 100% recycled mesh lining and responsibly sourced suede reflect growing environmental consciousness in outdoor gear manufacturing. However, this focus on sustainability comes with trade-offs in durability that become apparent during extended use, which I'll explore in detail throughout this review.

Design and Construction Analysis

The design philosophy behind the Vasque Sunsetter centers on modernizing classic hiking boot aesthetics while improving comfort and environmental impact. The one-piece suede upper eliminates potential failure points while providing a clean, timeless appearance that works equally well on mountain trails and city streets.

The molded mesh collar deserves particular attention - it's arguably the boot's most innovative feature. Unlike traditional padded collars that can retain moisture and create pressure points, this design hugs the ankle naturally while allowing air circulation. During my testing in humid conditions, this feature proved valuable for temperature regulation, though it does sacrifice some of the robust ankle support found in traditional Vasque hiking boots.

Construction Highlights

  • Upper Material: Premium suede leather with natural water resistance
  • Lining: 100% recycled mesh for sustainability and breathability
  • Waterproof Membrane: Nature-Tex with 50% recycled content
  • Footbed: Anatomical high-rebound design for all-day comfort
  • Lacing System: Traditional metal eyelets with spare lace set included

The Nature-Tex waterproofing represents Vasque's shift toward sustainable materials without compromising performance. In my experience, it performs comparably to Gore-Tex in terms of waterproofing and breathability, though the long-term durability remains to be proven. The membrane integrates seamlessly with the boot's construction, showing no delamination or hotspots after six months of regular use.

One area where the Sunsetter shows its modern design philosophy is in the midsole construction. The compression-molded EVA provides significantly more cushioning than traditional hiking boots, making it particularly suitable for hikers transitioning from running shoes. However, this comes at the cost of some stability on uneven terrain - a trade-off that reflects the boot's positioning as an everyday adventure shoe rather than a technical hiking boot.

Shop Women's Sunsetter Boots

The Vasque Micro Plus outsole features a relatively aggressive lug pattern that provides excellent traction on most surfaces. During testing on wet rocks, loose gravel, and muddy trails, the outsole performed admirably, though the compound feels slightly softer than traditional Vibram options. This translates to good grip but potentially faster wear on abrasive surfaces - another reflection of the boot's focus on comfort over extreme durability.

Trail Performance Testing

Real-world performance testing of the Vasque Sunsetter has been conducted across diverse environments, from desert canyons in Utah to temperate rainforests in the Pacific Northwest. This comprehensive evaluation reveals both the strengths and limitations of Vasque's modern approach to hiking boot design.

In dry conditions, the Sunsetter excels. The suede upper provides natural abrasion resistance, and the flexible design allows for natural foot movement on technical terrain. During a challenging ascent of Angel's Landing in Zion National Park, the boots provided adequate support while remaining comfortable during the 5-hour round trip. The grip on sandstone was particularly impressive, with the Micro Plus outsole providing confidence-inspiring traction on steep, smooth rock sections.

Performance Metrics

8.5/10
Comfort
8/10
Traction
7/10
Durability

Waterproofing performance has been thoroughly tested through stream crossings, rain hikes, and snow conditions. The Nature-Tex membrane consistently kept feet dry during water crossings up to mid-boot height, and breathability remained adequate during high-exertion activities. However, like all waterproof boots, they can become clammy during extended wear in warm conditions.

Where the Sunsetter shows its limitations is in extreme durability testing. Compared to traditional Vasque boots men's models, the softer suede shows wear more quickly when subjected to brush and rock abrasion. After 200+ miles of varied terrain, scuff marks and minor gouges are visible, though they don't affect waterproofing or structural integrity.

Compare with Vasque Breeze Series

Load-bearing performance with a 25-pound pack revealed the boot's sweet spot. The compression-molded EVA midsole provides excellent shock absorption for day hikes and overnight trips, but begins to feel less supportive during multi-day backpacking with heavier loads. For hikers primarily interested in day hiking and light backpacking, the comfort-to-support ratio is excellent.

My Personal Experience

My relationship with the Vasque Sunsetter began with skepticism. Having worn the original Sundowner for years, I was curious whether this modern interpretation could live up to the legacy while addressing contemporary hiking needs. After six months and over 300 miles of testing, I've developed a nuanced appreciation for what Vasque has accomplished.

The break-in period was remarkably gentle - a stark contrast to traditional hiking boots that require weeks of gradual conditioning. Within three short hikes totaling about 15 miles, the Sunsetter felt completely natural. This immediate comfort proved invaluable during a last-minute invitation to join a group hike in the Cascade Mountains, where I was able to wear them confidently without fear of blisters or hot spots.

One memorable test came during an early season attempt on Mount Washington's Tuckerman Ravine trail. The combination of snow, ice, mud, and rocky terrain provided an excellent proving ground for the boot's versatility. The Nature-Tex membrane kept my feet dry through snow and stream crossings, while the flexible design allowed for confident movement on technical sections. However, I did notice some heel slip on steep descents that wouldn't occur with more traditional, structured boots.

Trail Insight

A park ranger at Bryce Canyon mentioned that the Sunsetter's design works particularly well for visitors who want one boot for multiple activities - hiking, camping, and exploring towns. The versatile styling and comfort make them practical for the modern adventure traveler.

Seasonal performance varies notably. In summer conditions, the breathability is adequate but not exceptional - my feet stayed comfortable during moderate exertion but became noticeably warm during steep climbs in temperatures above 80°F. Spring and fall performance is excellent, with the waterproofing providing confidence during unpredictable weather while the insulation level remains appropriate for active hiking.

The most surprising aspect of living with these boots has been their versatility beyond hiking. The refined aesthetic and comfortable construction make them suitable for travel, casual wear, and light work applications. I've worn them confidently in urban environments, from airport terminals to restaurant patios, without feeling overdressed or out of place.

Explore Alternative Vasque Models

After extensive use, my overall impression is that the Sunsetter succeeds as a modern hiking boot for contemporary users. While it doesn't match the legendary durability of vintage Vasque shoes, it provides a more realistic solution for today's hiking patterns - shorter, more frequent adventures with emphasis on immediate comfort and style versatility.

Comparison and Value Analysis

Understanding where the Vasque Sunsetter fits in today's competitive hiking boot market requires comparison with both Vasque's own lineup and competitor offerings. The boot occupies a unique position between traditional hiking boots and modern athletic-inspired designs.

Vs. Original Sundowner

Weight: 30% lighter (997g vs 1400g)
Comfort: Superior cushioning and fit
Durability: Reduced (5+ years vs 15+ years)
Price: Similar ($200-250)
Sustainability: Much improved materials

Vs. Merrell Moab 3

Support: Better ankle stability
Waterproofing: Superior membrane
Style: More refined aesthetic
Price: 25% higher cost
Durability: Comparable longevity

Within Vasque's current lineup, the Sunsetter sits between the lighter Vasque Juxt and the more robust St. Elias. This positioning makes sense for hikers who want more support than a trail runner but less bulk than a traditional backpacking boot. The sustainable materials and modern comfort features justify the premium over budget alternatives.

User Review Summary

Amazon Customer (4/5 stars):

"Great fit and comfort for day hikes. The waterproofing works well, but I wish the leather was more durable for the price."

Reddit User r/CampingGear:

"These boots are comfortable out of the box, but don't expect Sundowner-level durability. Good for casual hikers, not for serious backpackers."

REI Customer Review:

"Love the style and immediate comfort. The narrow fit works well for my feet, and the waterproofing has been reliable through multiple seasons."

Value analysis reveals the Sunsetter as a solid mid-tier option. At $200-250, it costs significantly more than basic hiking boots but less than premium European models. The sustainable materials, modern comfort features, and Vasque's reputation support this pricing, though value-conscious hikers might find better durability elsewhere.

Potential Drawbacks

  • • Softer leather shows wear quickly
  • • Narrow fit doesn't suit all feet
  • • Less durable than original Sundowner
  • • Limited resoling options
  • • Premium price point

Key Advantages

  • • Excellent out-of-box comfort
  • • Reliable waterproofing
  • • Sustainable material construction
  • • Versatile styling for multiple uses
  • • Good traction on varied terrain
Compare with St. Elias Model

The Sunsetter represents Vasque's attempt to balance heritage with contemporary needs. For hikers who prioritize immediate comfort, sustainable materials, and versatile styling over maximum durability, it succeeds admirably. However, those seeking a buy-it-for-life boot should consider more traditional options or be prepared for replacement within 3-5 years depending on usage patterns.

Frequently Asked Questions

Are Vasque Sunsetter boots worth the investment?

The Vasque Sunsetter offers good value for hikers seeking a comfortable, waterproof boot with modern features. While not as durable as the legendary Sundowner, it provides excellent comfort and sustainable materials at a reasonable price point. Best suited for day hikes and light backpacking rather than extreme conditions. Consider your hiking frequency and intensity - if you hike more than 100 miles annually or tackle challenging terrain regularly, the investment is worthwhile. For occasional hikers, budget alternatives might suffice.

How does the Vasque Sunsetter compare to the original Sundowner?

The Sunsetter is lighter (997g vs 1200g+) and more comfortable than the original Sundowner, featuring modern cushioning and sustainable materials. However, it sacrifices some durability - the original Italian-made Sundowner was known for lasting decades, while the Sunsetter prioritizes comfort and lighter weight over extreme longevity. The waterproofing is comparable, but the newer Nature-Tex membrane offers better breathability than early Gore-Tex versions. Expect 3-5 years of regular use from the Sunsetter versus 10-15 years from vintage Sundowners.

What sizes and colors are available for the Vasque Sunsetter?

The Vasque Sunsetter is available in men's sizes 7-14 and women's sizes 6-12, both with half sizes. Color options include Lion (tan/brown), Ebony (dark brown/black), and Thyme (olive green). The boots tend to run slightly narrow, so wide-footed hikers may need to size up or consider alternative models. Women's versions are available in the same colorways with appropriate last adjustments. I recommend trying them on in-store if possible, as the fit differs significantly from athletic shoes and some other hiking boot brands.

Is the Nature-Tex waterproofing effective in wet conditions?

Yes, the Nature-Tex membrane provides reliable waterproofing for stream crossings, wet trails, and light snow. Made with 50% recycled materials, it offers breathability comparable to Gore-Tex. However, like all waterproof membranes, it requires proper DWR treatment maintenance on the outer leather to perform optimally. In my testing, it remained waterproof through 6+ inch stream crossings and extended rain exposure. Breathability is adequate for moderate exertion but can feel clammy during high-intensity activities in warm weather.

How long is the break-in period for Vasque Sunsetter boots?

The Vasque Sunsetter has a relatively short break-in period of 2-3 short hikes or about 15-20 miles of walking. The soft suede upper and padded collar minimize hot spots. I recommend wearing them around town for a few days before your first serious hike to ensure proper fit and comfort. Unlike traditional leather boots that require extensive conditioning and gradual break-in, the Sunsetter can be worn confidently on moderate hikes almost immediately. This makes them excellent for spontaneous adventures or hikers who don't want to invest time in boot conditioning.

Final Verdict and Recommendations

After extensive testing across diverse conditions and terrains, the Vasque Sunsetter emerges as a thoughtfully designed boot that successfully modernizes the hiking boot concept for contemporary users. While it doesn't replicate the legendary durability of its Sundowner predecessor, it offers a compelling combination of immediate comfort, sustainable construction, and versatile performance that aligns with modern hiking patterns.

The Sunsetter excels for hikers who prioritize comfort and convenience over maximum durability. If your typical adventures involve day hikes, weekend backpacking trips, and mixed-terrain exploration, these boots provide an excellent balance of support, weather protection, and all-day wearability. The sustainable materials and refined aesthetic add value for environmentally conscious consumers who appreciate gear that works in multiple contexts.

Best For:

  • • Day hikers seeking immediate comfort
  • • Weekend backpackers with light to moderate loads
  • • Travelers wanting versatile outdoor footwear
  • • Hikers transitioning from athletic shoes
  • • Environmentally conscious outdoor enthusiasts

However, traditional backpackers and those seeking maximum durability should consider alternatives. The softer leather construction and comfort-focused design make the Sunsetter less suitable for extreme conditions, heavy loads, or users who expect decade-plus service life. For serious mountaineering or extended expeditions, more robust options like the Vasque hiking boots men's St. Elias series would be more appropriate.

8.2/10
Overall Rating
Excellent for intended use
$200-250
Price Range
Fair value proposition
3-5
Expected Years
Regular use lifespan

The Nature-Tex waterproofing and sustainable construction represent positive steps forward in outdoor gear manufacturing. While some durability has been sacrificed for comfort and environmental responsibility, this trade-off reflects changing consumer priorities and usage patterns. Most modern hikers will find the 3-5 year lifespan acceptable given the immediate comfort and performance benefits.

Shop All Vasque Hiking Boots

My recommendation is straightforward: if you hike regularly but not intensively, value immediate comfort and sustainable construction, and appreciate versatile styling, the Vasque Sunsetter is an excellent choice. It successfully modernizes the hiking boot concept without losing sight of core performance requirements. For explorers of women's hiking boots options, the Sunsetter offers the same balanced approach in gender-specific fits and colorways.

The Sunsetter represents Vasque's vision for the future of hiking footwear - lighter, more comfortable, and more sustainable than traditional boots while maintaining essential performance characteristics. Whether this vision aligns with your hiking needs depends on your priorities, but for the majority of contemporary hikers, the Sunsetter succeeds admirably in delivering a modern interpretation of classic outdoor footwear.
